Award.AwardTitle: CRII: ACI: Transforming Semiautomatic Patient-Specific Simulation Workflows into Autonomous Medical Imaging-Through-Analysis Tools

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
While finite element simulations are well established in medical research, their potential for every-day use in clinical practice still lies largely idle. One of the major reasons is the process of building patient-specific computational models, including transfer of diagnostic imaging data to explicit surfaces, geometry cleanup and boundary-fitted mesh generation. Although powerful software solutions to streamline this process are available today, many simulation workflows involving complex physiological geometries still require the intervention of specially trained analysts. The associated cost and time implications do not fit into many clinical processes characterized by tight budgets and urgent decision-making. The goal of this project is to initiate research activities that provide a pathway to a closer integration of predictive simulation in clinical decision-making and help unlock its potential in clinical routines. The developed concepts and methods can be applied in the context of the timely diagnosis and management of osteoporosis and vascular disease that constitute significant challenges for the US healthcare system. The discoveries and clinical tools evolving from this research have the potential to transform current healthcare protocols, thus improving the well-being of a large portion of the elderly population in the US. Therefore, this research aligns with the NSF mission to promote the progress of science and to advance the national health, prosperity and welfare.

From a technical viewpoint, this project envisions seamless imaging-through-analysis procedures that enable the full automation of predictive biomedical simulations from reading in diagnostic imaging data to the output of clinically relevant simulation results. To this end, it focuses on establishing the mathematical, algorithmic and technical foundations of diffuse geometry based finite element analysis applied to clinically relevant problems in bone mechanics and biofluids. The central point is the extension of the phase-field concept to the description of all interface related information, such as location or normal directions, in a diffuse sense. In the context of fuzzy imaging data, diffuse geometric models can be generated automatically by integrating unsupervised medical image processing techniques with variational segmentation methods. Diffuse geometry can enable specialized finite element methods that transfer all variational boundary and interface integrals into volume integrals, so that any form of explicit surface tracking is avoided. This project aims to demonstrate accuracy, robustness, and error control in diffuse geometry based simulations, in particular within the range of physiologically relevant flow regimes. It also can demonstrate the potential of diffuse geometry methods in autonomous cyberinfrastructure for osteoporosis prediction, preoperative planning for orthopedics, and liver perfusion analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While patient-specific simulations are established in medical research, their potential in everyday clinical practice still lies largely idle. The overarching objective of this NSF project was to initiate research on transforming standard semi-automatic model building procedures into novel fully automated simulation workflows that can be operated independently in hospitals and clinics by clinical personnel without expert knowledge in computation and associated software.

On the intellectual merit side, the project produced a novel methodology that is able to seamlessly integrate diagnostic image segmentation and predictive multiscale simulation in a common finite element framework. Its new components developed in this project include: (a) a two-stage variational approach for segmenting 3D bone CT data that performs robustly with respect to thin cartilage interfaces; (b) simple multiscale predictor/corrector schemes that enable accurate physiology-based finite element simulation in terms of a series of small uncoupled systems at a fraction of the computing power and memory required by the fully coupled voxel-scale system; (c) novel diffuse interface methods that eliminate the need for manually constructing explicit surfaces for boundary and interface conditions; (d) algorithms for combining diffuse and sharp CAD models. A proof-of-concept computational framework was successfully tested and validated for the automatic load capacity analysis of patient-specific vertebrae and the simulation-based performance analysis of coupled bone/implant configurations in close collaboration with clinical researchers at the Academic Health Center of the University of Minnesota.

From a broader impacts viewpoint, the following outcomes were achieved as part of this NSF project. Bone related diseases such as osteoporosis and associated fractures affect a significant portion of the elderly population in the US. The results of this NSF project clearly demonstrate that computational tools can help transform current healthcare protocols for a more accurate prediction and more reliable early diagnosis of bone diseases. The project provided significant opportunities for training and professional development, contributing to the overall goal of developing and maintaining a well-trained STEM workforce. The two undergraduate and four graduate students involved in this NSF project were trained in methods related to computational and data-enabled science and engineering. In addition, the project activities required interdisciplinary exchange and team work between different members of the group and other researchers, fostering communication skills and collaborative thinking across disciplinary boundaries. All students gave at least one 45-minute seminar presentation and at least one 15-minute conference presentation during the active project period.

Another outcome of this NSF project is the initiation of synergistic interdisciplinary collaborations with researchers in biomedical engineering and clinical areas at the University of Minnesota. These include Jeff Calder (image processing), Alex Fok (biomaterials, imaging), Joan Bechtold (orthopedic surgery), Takashi Takahashi (radiology), Jonathan Braman (shoulder surgery), Paula Ludewig (physical therapy), and Marc Tompkins (sports medicine). These collaborations are evidenced by co-authored papers (Bechtold, Calder, Takahashi), co-supervision of students (Bechtold, Calder, Takahashi), and other active or submitted research grants (Bechtold, Braman, Fok, Ludewig).

The novel methods and scientific findings accomplished in this NSF project extend the base of knowledge in the disciplinary fields of computational science, biomedical simulation, and patient-specific imaging-based simulation. They were disseminated to the scientific research community through eight presentations at national and international conferences and eight articles in peer-reviewed scientific journals.
